thread.title: Rams DC Wade Phillips inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame
thread.title_full: Rams DC Wade Phillips inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame

title: Rams DC Wade Phillips inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame

organizations.name: texas sports hall of fame rams

text:
Rams DC Wade Phillips inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame Rams DC Wade Phillips inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame By Tanya Ray Fox 14 hours ago 20 shares By: Tanya Ray Fox | 14 hours ago 
On Tuesday night, Los Angeles Rams defensive coordinator Wade Phillips will join former Rams defensive back Dave Elmendorf as two of the eight members of the 2017 Texas Sports Hall of Fame class. 
Phillips, a native of Orange, TX, played his collegiate football at the University of Houston as a linebacker. He first began coaching in the NFL with the Houston Oilers, under the tutelage of his famed father Bum Phillips, before embarking on a successful, four-decade career. Related: 
Here’s an excerpt from the Texas Sports Hall of Fame press release: 
“…Phillips has held multiple NFL positions, including head coaching stints with the Denver Broncos, Buffalo Bills and Dallas Cowboys. Phillips added to his legacy by being named the 2015 NFL Assistant Coach of Year and orchestrating a phenomenal defensive performance in Super Bowl 50 that led to a Broncos victory. Phillips met his wife Laurie at PNG in 1964, where she was the head cheerleader and he was the starting QB. In 2017 Phillips was hired as the defensive coordinator by the Los Angeles Rams.” 
Elmendorf was a career L.A. Ram, playing safety from 1971-1979. The Houston native also played football and baseball at Texas A&M, for whom he currently serves as a radio color commentator. Related: 
Here’s some more from the press release : 
“…In 1971, he was drafted to play baseball by the New York Yankees but chose to play football for the Los Angeles Rams. He was drafted in the 3rd round of the 1971 NFL Draft, earning all-rookie honors his first season. In his nine NFL seasons Elmendorf played in 130 games, starting all 130, intercepting 27 passes and recovering 10 fumbles. After the NFL he became a broadcaster on radio and TV and serves as the color commentator for the Texas A&M football radio broadcasts, as well as being involved in other business enterprises. In 1997 he was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame and in 2016 into the Southwest Conference Hall of Fame.” The rest of the 2017 class includes: – Former Dallas Cowboys All Pro safety Darren Woodson – 2008 Olympic all-around gymnastics champion Nastia Liukin – University of Texas track & football star Eric Metcalf – Texas A&M University track & field coach Pat Henry – Former Houston Cougars NCAA women’s volleyball player Flo Hyman – Former Houston Cougars NCAA women’s volleyball player Rita Buck-Crockett More Latest Rams news!
